name: The Witcher 3 HUD
description: A minimalist reimagination of The Witcher 3 in-game interface for the sake of a better visibility while in combat and exploring.
roles: UX research, UI Design & Motion Animation

content_blocks.title: The UI is far from sight

block_paragraphs.paragraph: The stamina bar, due to its positioning, is uncomfortable to look at because it is too far from the screen's center.
This becomes a problem because it requires the player to constantly take their eyes off the combat or the road.

block_multimedia.note: During combat, in order to check stats, the player has to make a long eye movement.
While exploring, players say they pay more attention to the minimap, which is far from the center of the screen.

block_paragraphs.paragraph: Looking at the action RPG and exploration game industry, we found some solutions to these problems that would fit perfectly into The Witcher 3.
On one hand, we have games like Skyrim and Elden Ring, which use a compass for navigating the world (a feature even requested by The Witcher 3 players)
For managing stamina, one of the best examples is Zelda with its Stamina Wheel, as well as other games that feature resource management within the player's field of view.

content_blocks.title: Using what we know to rethink the UI

block_paragraphs.paragraph: The proposed solution involves turning the stamina bar into a dynamic wheel that follows Geralt's lower body during combat.
For navigation, the map was hidden, and a compass was implemented.
The first version of the project was created as a college assignment.
After months, I revisited the project (and the game itself) and found several problems. I then determined that the solutions were incomplete and needed adjustments and an overall expansion.

block_multimedia.note: Unnecessarily large icons and the health bar still make the player divert their eyes from the fight.
The compass didn’t have enough contrast and needed a North direction indicator.

block_paragraphs.paragraph: Due to the insights gathered from the first version, here is the list of changes I implemented in the latest version:
▪ Add the remaining original UI elements to the wheel.
▪ Make parts of the UI appear dynamically depending on the situation.
▪ Decrease all bar sizes and adjust the size of the sign icons.
▪ Expand the elements of the compass.
▪ Style the elements to more closely match the original UI.
For the final version, I included the remaining UI elements in the wheel, completely removing the original elements from the corner.
On top of that, some quality-of-life changes were made. For example:
▪ Making the rest of the UI low opacity while using Igni.
▪ Showing only the health bar while healing out of combat.
The compass was modified to be visible on both dark and light backgrounds and designed to be more compatible with the rest of the UI.

block_multimedia.note: Traveling while healing - Wheel + Compass HUD

conclusion.paragraph: With this project, I learned the complexity of designing a UI that balances both immersion and utility. The Witcher 3 is a great example of a game so vast it requires a reliable way to navigate it, and so mechanically rich that it needs a UI providing all the necessary information for the player to understand the game.
It was a joy to create a case study for one of my most beloved games, even if it was only a personal project.
